txt.en: Deep in the Ambarûli marshes, Gurakhu is the nesting place of zizani, the creatures known in other parts of Middle-earth as Neekers.

Ordâkhai soldiers have established an encampment at Khetsok, on the south side of the Ikorbân River. From here they contest the Dumûri for control of the Wrackwade river-crossing and regulate access to Ambarûl from the south.

As the Ordâkhai lose their grip on Ambarûl, lawlessness is on the rise. Cutthroats and ruffians, many of whom are Ordâkhai deserters, have formed a camp at Bidrokh-nûn from which they prey on the locals and any trade caravans using the nearby road.

Soldiers of the Great Southern Empire of Ordâkh who survived the Ambarûli revolt have regrouped at Omboha. Unable to reach their compatriots south of the Ikorbân, they gather their strength while awaiting an unlikely rescue.
The dry sands of Nirikal in southern Ambarûl provide the perfect habitat for the usan-kûni, the giant scorpions of Shagâna.
At the site of a ruin of unknown origin, Ambarûli servals and caracals have made a comfortable home for themselves.
The hills of Tûl Ushu in north-eastern Ambarûl are home to many usan-kûni, the giant scorpions of Shagâna.
Explore enemy camps, settlements, and lairs in Ambarûl in the Ikorbân Valley.
Explore enemy camps, settlements, and lairs in Ambarûl in the Ikorbân Valley.
Shegdush, \qswine-home\q in Shagani, is the favoured stomping ground of the wild boars of eastern Ambarûl.
In the marshes on the southern shores of the Ikorbân, scather-gnats gather in Umûn Khab.

Once the primary fishing village of Ambarûl, Eshadûr has fallen to Ordâkhai occupation. After being defeated by Girhâzi and the Ambarûli revolt, the majority of Ordâkhai forces fled south of the Ikorbân, pushed out Eshadûr's former residents, and made it their new base of operations. From here they test the Dumûri defences and await reinforcements from the south so that they may take Iridír and northern Ambarûl back into their control.
